conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to use the properties of a paraboloid and the geometry of light reflection and refraction.
The key is to determine the path of the light as it reflects off the paraboloid and enters the hemispherical lens.
The height of the car headlights from the ground is 92.8 cm.
The radius of the hemispherical lens is denoted as R.
The focal length f of the paraboloid is given by f = (1/4)R.
The distance from the light source to the focal point F is F = (1/4)R = 23.6 cm.
The light travels from the light source to the focal point F, then reflects off the paraboloid, and finally enters the hemispherical lens.
The distance from F to the light-blocking plate is 92.8 cm - 23.6 cm = 69.2 cm.
The refractive index n = 4/3 affects the path of the light but does not directly affect the length of the transparent part.
The length of the transparent part of the light is 69.2 cm.
